Global Risk-On / Risk-Off Positioning Tone

CoT market tone: risk-on vs risk-off positioning.

As of 2026-01-06

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The CoT Market Tone signal (1) indicates a Neutral market tone as of 2026-01-06, with a net tone z-score of -0.001568.
  • This reflects a stable balance between crowded long and crowded short positions across futures markets.
  • Conviction Band: Low, Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence, Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The net tone, calculated as the difference between crowded long (0.219653) and crowded short shares (0.222543), is near zero (-0.002890), indicating balanced speculative sentiment (1).
  • The robust z-score of -0.001568 falls well within the Neutral regime threshold (-0.5 to 0.5), showing no strong directional bias.
  • Conditional Invalidation: A sustained move in the CoT Market Tone z-score above 0.5 (Risk-On) or below -0.5 (Risk-Off) would reverse this neutral interpretation.

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant; risks balanced. The market tone is currently balanced with no strong speculative bias.
  • Upside secondary: A shift to Risk-On could occur if crowded long positions significantly increase relative to shorts.
  • Downside residual: A move to Risk-Off would be triggered by a substantial rise in crowded short positioning breadth.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Tactical (weeks), as it reflects weekly shifts in speculative positioning from CoT data.
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: Low, given the current neutral state and low conviction in a strong directional signal.

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal primarily informs cross-asset positioning and sentiment (2).
  • It generally indicates a mid-cycle or consolidating market phase when neutral.
  • It typically interacts with volatility (e.g., VIX) and credit spread signals to confirm risk regime transitions.

Data & References:

  • CoT Market Tone DataFrame, latest observation 2026-01-06.
  • The `net_tone` (-0.002890) and `CoT_Market_Tone_z` (-0.001568) are most influential.
  • Additional public datasets like the VIX Market Volatility Signal (3) or Credit Spreads Signal (4) would enhance reliability.
